Title: The Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain
Content: The Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain is a mountain range in the Pacific Ocean. All mountains in the Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain were formed from volcanic activity. Most of the mountains are classified as seamounts. The difference between an island and a seamount is that an island rises above sea level and a seamount does not.

Scientists determined the ages of the rocks that form the mountains of the Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain. The map shows for each seamount or island its location, its age in millions of years (my), and its distance from the island of Hawaii.

The island of Hawaii is the only island in the Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain currently experiencing volcanic activity. Scientists have proposed a theory that states that the mountains of the Hawaiian–Emperor Seamount Chain form at a hotspot where magma rises from Earth's mantle. As the Pacific Plate moves, new volcanic mountains form over the hotspot. The diagram shows the hotspot theory.
